1121891214507368453.text:
Complete formal semantics of x86 in #kframework, by @vadve and @RosuGrigore's labs at UIUC in collaboration with @rv_inc. To be presented @PLDI'19. You can now use the K tool ecosystem to symbolically execute and formally verify x86 binaries, too.
http://fsl.cs.illinois.edu/FSL/papers/2019/dasgupta-park-kasampalis-adve-rosu-2019-pldi/dasgupta-park-kasampalis-adve-rosu-2019-pldi-public.pdf …pic.twitter.com/JUH4pnzp45

1121815705584898048.text: Now we are happy to announce the completion of an extra layer of security: "formal verification". It was a huge effort by @rv_inc and done with support from @ethereumecf. Gnosis will soon start moving funds to this verified version of the contract. (2/2)https://blog.gnosis.pm/formal-verification-a-journey-deep-into-the-gnosis-safe-smart-contracts-b00daf354a9c …

1121784213462822917.text: We just formally verified our smart contracts!  If the term formal verification seems a little confusing, don't fear! Let's take a journey deep into the world of formal verification and your confusion will be transformed into clarity. https://blog.gnosis.pm/formal-verification-a-journey-deep-into-the-gnosis-safe-smart-contracts-b00daf354a9c …pic.twitter.com/zdWNxC0MmA

1121793225352601602.text: The formal verification of @gnosisSafe contracts is completed. It took several engineers several months. Thank you to @rv_inc for the collaboration and @ethereumecf for co-funding it!https://blog.gnosis.pm/formal-verification-a-journey-deep-into-the-gnosis-safe-smart-contracts-b00daf354a9c …

1044983326686175232.text: ERC777-K is parametric in the execution environment. https://goo.gl/z6cSLx  It can be plugged-and-played within any execution environment which has a formal semantics, such as a virtual machine or a programming language. #ERC777 #ethereum Demohttps://youtu.be/2JWxt0N721Y

1044277941998407680.text: Being executable, ERC777-K has been thoroughly tested: https://goo.gl/z6cSLx  We provide more than 200 unit tests for ERC777-K, which can be also used for potential ERC777 implementations to check if they conform to the standard. #ERC777 #ethereum Videohttps://youtu.be/2JWxt0N721Y

1098743308833222656.text:
Fun and relatively new fact: the smallest solution `a` of the equation below when `N = 896` has more than 2 trillion digits.
http://ami.ektf.hu/uploads/papers/finalpdf/AMI_43_from29to41.pdf …
I should stop being interested in this problem.  Definitely.pic.twitter.com/zWaLxDy8GB

1096926302437761024.text:
The new Haskell implementation of K just passed 70,000 LOC:
https://github.com/kframework/kore .  Cannot wait to get rid of the current slow and buggy Java implementation.  Thanks @InputOutputHK for funding this monumental effort (more than 2000 commits and 20 contributors)!

1096030408687403008.text:
Should KEVM (https://jellopaper.org/ ) become the canonical EVM spec?
Pros: formal, executable, yields VM, symbolic execution, contract verifier, etc., all correct-by-construction.
Cons: harder to understand, due to notation
Tell us what you think at
https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/jello-paper-as-canonical-evm-spec/2389 ….

1092893292981825536.text:
Nice to see two Panvala grants building on the K framework!  Congratulations to the proposing teams (not shown in the table, but they are not associated with @rv_inc nor any of the creators/maintainers of K as far as I can tell).
https://medium.com/@Panvala/twelve-grants-awarded-in-batch-one-of-panvala-token-grants-59b8df7422fe …https://twitter.com/PanvalaMark/status/1091378982191284224 …

1092766895349161990.text: PL folks might be interested in attending LangDev'19 in Amsterdam, 21-22 March 2019: http://langdevcon.org/ .  A quick way to see some language frameworks in action, and talk to their developers.

1091468356669095937.text:
The K Tutorial is now available in Japanese, too: https://github.com/ammkrn/k_framework_tutorial_jp …
Great job @ammkrn!

1090742812134518784.text:
Will give an intensive one-week seminar on K (http://kframework.org ) at SETTS'19 in Chongqing, China, during April 21-27, 2019. 
 http://www.swu-rise.net.cn/SETSS2019/ 
Will cover the basics, but will also briefly discuss the semantics of C, Java, JavaScript, EVM, IELE, Solidity, Plutus.

1083658253320507392.text:
"KEVM folks" = @rv_inc 
Besides advantages mentioned at https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/jello-paper-as-canonical-evm-spec/2389 …, the major missing one is that KEVM serves as the input to a program verifier for smart contracts.  In other words, it reduces the gap between what you run and what you formally verify to 0 (zero).https://twitter.com/expede/status/1083483160837419008 …

1077544924109815808.text: I meant from now on, of course.

1077543614006390784.text:
Xmas decision: I will never be on the PC of any conference that requires me to attend a physical PC meeting.
http://fsl.cs.illinois.edu/grosu pic.twitter.com/OXFwaVxEuk

1073977013982150657.text: It was a delight to attend Plutusfest and chat with Philip Wadler, @sol3gga, their students, and the Plutus team.  Also realized this was the first time in 20 years that I attended an event only to watch others' work, not to present mine.  So relaxing :-)https://forum.cardano.org/t/recap-plutusfest-2018-in-edinburgh-scotland/18560 …

1072635856656232448.text: Thanks, Phil.  As you know, we usually prefer to prove full correctness, but when that is not possible, statistical model checking is the best next thing.https://twitter.com/phildaian/status/1072595028961320960 …

1070012238797438976.text: As part of the first Ethereum security grant, @rv_inc completed the initial formal specification and verification (both deductive proofs and statistical model checking) of Casper and Randao.  Comments and suggestionsfor next steps are welcome.  https://runtimeverification.com/blog/runtime-verification-completes-formal-verification-of-ethereum-casper-protocol/ …

1065015369025445888.text: Good argument.  In my experience thou, many abstracts do not make it into papers, people do not bid before they see the paper, and deadline extensions do not make a difference (on the contrary, make the conference look weaker).  TACAS'19 did reject, even with artifact submitted.https://twitter.com/GermanVidalUPV/status/1065012437370503168 …

1065006789417156608.text: Can anybody make a good case in favor of separate abstract and paper submission deadlines?  My group failed to submit at least 5 good papers over the last few years simply because we missed the stupid "abstract deadline".

1061506967330533377.text: Yes.  Had a Toyota gift rejected, or withdrawn, but not because of nationality and because of overhead.  University wanted to charge overhead, Toyota didn't.  Maybe if you pay overhead ...https://twitter.com/tiarkrompf/status/1061389826124066816 …

1061490007641350144.text: Agreed.  In fact, we believe they should include complete details on the specification.  That's how we do our audits at @rv_inc (https://runtimeverification.com/smartcontract/ ); we call them audits, but they are full fledged formal verification of EVM bytecode against formal specifications.https://twitter.com/ptsankov/status/1061231857516363776 …

1053127386978570240.text: We found the YP both incomplete and hard to read. We are biased, of course, but we believe that KEVM is as simple and clear as it can be. See the Jello Paper https://jellopaper.org , automatically generated from KEVM.  @rv_inc @phildaianhttps://twitter.com/benjaminion_xyz/status/1052818874905845761 …

1044221905836929025.text: Hopefully it is becoming increasingly clear that, at more than $1M value per line of code, only the irresponsible players forego formal verification.

1044221767303213056.text: Very interesting talk by @phildaian (now at Cornell)!  Of course, all smart contracts must be formally specified & verified.  Albeit formal verification only guarantees correctness wrt the formal spec, which is often much harder to write than the contract.  And may have flaws.https://twitter.com/phildaian/status/1044204284898873344 …

1043885769335738370.text: Unbelievalbe, almost.  Same like the problem where the smallest solution of `a/(b+c) + b/(a+c) + c/(a+b) = 4` has more than 80 digits.https://twitter.com/vardi/status/1043866558118985729 …

1042763023352520706.text:
Always enjoy watching this machine struggling to compute 1/0.
Although, it burns a lot of gas for nothing.  We know it from the EVM that 1/0 is obviously 0.  And in case you wonder, 0^0 is of course 1.https://twitter.com/Rainmaker1973/status/1042037848915042304 …

1042004859749380096.text: As K creator, it is so refreshing to see this. All based on just the operational semantics of EVM.  Academics need to wake up!  They still believe (and teach) that to formally verify programs for L, you first need a custom (Hoare) logic for L, then a VC generator, etc; or an IVL.https://twitter.com/MakerDAO/status/1041795771639652353 …

1041300586120073216.text: PL folks: are there conventional (ie, interpret lam and app as functions) models of untyped lambda for which equational deduction is *complete*? Hindley-Longo models are complete but non-conventional. Graph models are conventional but incomplete? @lambda_calculus @ShriramKMurthi

1040039660330868736.text:
https://youtu.be/33VN5NIlGAc 
Excellent IELE (https://github.com/runtimeverification/iele-semantics …) intro by @SebastienGllmt of @emurgo_io .

IELE, or "blockchain LLVM", was created by @rv_inc in collaboration with @InputOutputHK and @vadve's and my students.

Automatically generated from its formal spec (in K).

1014782312482033665.text:
IELE testnet to be launched this month by @InputOutputHK in collaboration with @rv_inc.  IELE is a more secure alternative to EVM.  Also human-readable.  It is LLVM-like and designed from scratch using formal methods. VM generated automatically from spec.

992969332165611521.text:
12-yo son: Dad, why do you have a beard?
Me: I'd spend 10min/day to shave it, which is about 1h/week.  That's 52h/year, so a week of work.  Worse, that's the best work time in the day for me and all I'd do is watch my own face.  No, thanks.  I can write a paper in a good week.

Me: We need a new formal semanticist to help define the C++ semantics.
My team: Nope, we need a C++ expert.  K is easier to master than C++.

Don't know if I should feel proud or insulted ... but they won.

942747378305650688.text:
Just sent my mother (in Romania) money as holidays gift.

US bank got $35 fee for transfer.  Romanian bank got $25 fee for receiving money and converted at rate $1 = 3.7 RON, although actual rate is $1 = 3.9 RON.  Transfer will take 5 business days.

Down with the banks!

941642466331103237.text:
Time has come to design languages/VMs properly: through formal (executable) semantics!  Implementations and formal analysis tools result automatically, correct by construction.  Say NO to design-by-adhoc-implementation.

Let IELE serve as an example for how things should be done.https://twitter.com/rv_inc/status/941638649439014913 …

941452162865029120.text:
Nice update on EVM semantics by @_lunar_mining:
https://www.coindesk.com/yellowing-paper-whats-delaying-crucial-ethereum-update/amp/ …

I am of course biased (KEVM), but in my experience any language semantics which is not executable, or formally related to an executable one, is short-lived.  Being heavy on math and with errors is the worst.

901231922944364544.text: Fully agree with @vardi: accept until proven reject.  PC members cannot safely select more than 10% of the best papers.  Students suffer.https://twitter.com/vardi/status/901214641086488576 …

900895663701061632.text: In its defense, like clang VCC also issues a warning ... So still programmer's job to ensure definedness, cannot just trust prover.  Really?

900894623417151488.text: Ha, the VCC program verifier (http://rise4fun.com/Vcc/ ) proves this undefined program returns 4!  Replace 4 with 3 and it cannot prove it.pic.twitter.com/whIQKgSSvQ

900722436743868419.text:
https://runtimeverification.com/match/docs/runningexamples/ …
explains the undefined behavior in this example, as well as many other crazier ones.  Have fun.pic.twitter.com/mR7vPRYPWd

900349671998070784.text: What is the smallest (undefined) C program that returns different results with -O1 vs -O3 with gcc?  Here is a start: 255 vs. 0.pic.twitter.com/sROvsZbvbe

900152205768097794.text: For maximum fun and non-sense, the following "equivalent" program is in fact well-defined (but non-deterministic).pic.twitter.com/ndYSK4FWU4

899987954587885568.text: Nice to see real language designers serious about formal semantics.  Things move.  We need better tools derived automatically from semanticshttps://twitter.com/patrick_m19/status/899987132957294593 …

899839413819252736.text: I should have added *interesting* undefined program (different behaviors with different compilers).

896004482714263552.text:
Matching Logic (ML) paper finally done: http://fsl.cs.illinois.edu/index.php/Matching_logic ….
ML is the foundation of K, and subsumes separation and many other logics.

894631998366633984.text: Forgot to mention: RV-Match is based on a complete and open-source K formal semantics of the ISO C11 Standard: https://github.com/kframework/c-semantics ….

894625737172541441.text: RV-Match finds more undefined behaviors than tis-interpreter: https://runtimeverification.com/blog/?p=307 .  Easier to run, too, plus library support.
